description: A scaly patch that typically appears on sun-exposed skin.
symptoms: Red, scaly patches that may be rough, tender, or itchy.

symptoms: A pearly or waxy bump, a flat, scaly patch, or a red, itchy area.
treatment: Mohs surgery, excision, or radiation therapy

description: A group of noncancerous skin growths.
symptoms: Smooth, waxy, or scaly bumps, often brown, tan, or black.
treatment: Usually no treatment needed, but can be removed for cosmetic reasons

description: A noncancerous growth of the skin's connective tissue.
symptoms: A firm, red or brown bump, usually painless.
treatment: Usually no treatment needed, but can be removed for cosmetic reasons or if bothersome

description: The most serious type of skin cancer. It can spread to other parts of the body.
symptoms: An irregular mole that changes in size, shape, or color.
treatment: Early detection and surgical removal are crucial. Advanced stages may require additional therapies.

description: Common brown or black spots on the skin. Most are harmless.
symptoms: A new mole or an existing mole that changes in size, shape, or color.
treatment: Usually no treatment needed, but suspicious moles may be biopsied or removed.

description: Reddish growths caused by abnormal blood vessels.
symptoms: Red, purple, or blue bumps or patches.
treatment: Treatment depends on the type and severity. May include laser therapy, sclerotherapy, or surgery.
